This reuses [conventional go build machinery](https://github.com/golang/go/wiki/Modules#how-can-i-track-tool-dependencies-for-a-module) to simplify build.go, as suggested by @imsodin at #7552. `go generate` just works, without having genxdr or counterfeiter installed. `go mod tidy` no longer removes counterfeiter.

There's more work to be done on this front, in particular wrt. protobufs, but I figured I'd send a PR to test the waters and see if you want to move in this direction at all.

This makes us use TLS 1.3+ on sync connections by default. A new option
`insecureAllowOldTLSVersions` exists to allow communication with TLS
1.2-only clients (roughly Syncthing 1.2.2 and older). Even with that
option set you get a slightly simplified setup, with the cipher suite
order fixed instead of auto detected.

### Purpose

This addresses recommendations from LGTM about Semicolon insertion (https://lgtm.com/rules/4860080/). This change makes the JavaScript more consistent and predictable.

### Testing

I have not performed any testing. I do not believe the function of the program will be changed by this pull request. Automated testing should be sufficient for this PR.

### Documentation

This will not change the way the code runs for the user.

I noticed a weird failure event on sentry: `got deleted file that doesn't exist locally as needed when pulling on send-only`
https://sentry.syncthing.net/syncthing/syncthing/issues/10537/?environment=Stable&referrer=alert_email
Its informational only - the condition is not acted upon (the item is just ignored). It will lead to incorrect remote out-of-sync status for the affected device on other devices.

Most likely the cause is #7476, where now invalid files are considered needed. In that PR I only handled that case in send-receive folders, and forgot about the send-only folder having its own `pull` method.

I also took the opportunity to use `fileInfoBatch` instead of the "legacy manual way" (no behaviour change).
The validation now can also kick in when the path is empty, which produced a JS error.

Instead of immediately exiting when encountering an error setting up the API client, the error is stored and returned if the api client is used. That ensures that the error does not come up if no operation involving the API is happening (like just querying `--help`).

To do so I added an interface for the api client and an `errorAPIClient` type that returns the error from setup when on all of it's methods.

We watch folder label to update the path if it hasn't been modified yet. However if the same folder is opened again, the folder label doesn't change and thus the watch isn't triggered. Now `$scope.currentFolder` is cleared when the modal is closed, thus the watch gets trigered.
Parses are only used when the input field is changed, thus not when we update the value from javascript. Change it to be a validator, which is used whenever the value changes.

When a folder is removed we remove the marker. But there may be things
stored in it that have usefulness past the lifetime of the folder in
Syncthing, in particularly the folder ID marker for encrypted folders.

This changes the behavior to remove empty markers (or if the marker's a
file...) but otherwise rename it to `.stfolder.removed-$timestamp` so
that it's out of the way but the contents aren't lost.

This is intended as an enhancement for #7560, to make failed login attempts more easily visible even when the audit log is disabled.  Inspired by [this forum discussion](https://forum.syncthing.net/t/can-the-syncthing-web-gui-report-authentication-errors/16642).  The log level is kept to Info to avoid message panels in an already connected GUI.
Missed checking in this file in #7567.

No longer hide the web UI controls for the new untrusted/encrypted
device feature. Testing hasn't been very widespread, but there has been
some and quite a few bugs have been caught and fixed. I believe its time
to not hide it anymore, and cautiously recommend usage. E.g. mention
that the feature hasn't been widely used yet and anyone using it is an
early adopter, but drop the bit about not using it with production data.
We can maybe stress the need for backups in general and especially
using this.

To remove the feature flag I added a new type of config migration like on dbs:
Changes something, buti not the schema.

### Purpose

I tried to work on https://github.com/syncthing/syncthing/issues/6408 but I couldn't make it work. angular and jquery and all that is weird.. we should move the gui to react :D. 

Anyway, I tried to fix that issue but I couldn't, but on the way there, I made the 4 modals more consistent, so the code is the same for all four. It might get out of sync again if people change only one, so some funcs might have been better, but I didn't want to overcomplicate before I could actually fix the issue.

I added a `defaultPerPage` that the first time you open the modal is activated, and if you change it to say `25`, it will stay `25` on that modal.

### Testing

I tested it locally.

Reuses the bits from https://github.com/syncthing/syncthing/pull/7552 that aren't related to nfpm (which requires go1.16), to fix #7548. Fixing as in not using `--deb-systemd` that was broken upstream, and doesn't get any attention, but restarting services in a script of our own. This is also a behaviour change, as `--deb-systemd` enables the service on install. I personally like that change: I dislike programs that enable their daemons automatically (thought that seems to be standard practice).

No testing yet: I was too lazy to install ruby or build/download the docker - will test after CI built something.

This fixes #7557, where we use the protocol method `IsEncryptedParent` with a native path, while protocol operates on `/`-delimited paths only - thus it fails. Now this helper method accepts a list of path components, thus requiring the caller to use the proper method to split paths. And I created such a method for native paths, living in `lib/fs/utils.go` and replaces various calls to `strings.Split(...` with that.

### Purpose

This enables usage of the audit log to e.g. automatically block remote addresses from connecting after repeated login failures, as requested [on the forum](https://forum.syncthing.net/t/can-the-syncthing-web-gui-report-authentication-errors/16642/11).

### Testing

Manual verification of the audit log contents when the API authorization is enabled.

### Documentation

**TODO**: No docs PR prepared yet, waiting on feedback whether this is the right approach or if there are any other security implications.

Switches from fpm to nfpm to create debian packages.  
Written in go, no docker image or ruby required. Seems well maintained and if a version is faulty, it's easy to "control" through modules.

nfpm doesn't have the functionality to handle systemd units. I thus created a unified post-inst script using templating for all our packages. It restarts running systemd services if any, otherwise it sends `HUP`.

I changed the build tag for `build.go` to `build` such that `go mod tidy` doesn't remove the modules needed there (some new go1.16 thing).

Testing: Installed the syncthing package, did restart and still works. And diffing the new extracted .deb against the old only shows expected differences.

This also means we can retire the syncthing/builder docker image, once TC is adjusted to not use that.

### Purpose

Discovery failure info has been moved to a separate modal view in #4048.  The same treatment is in order for the listener failures. Additionally, it would be nice to know what these entries mean even when there are no failures. As discussed [on the forum](https://forum.syncthing.net/t/first-contact-what-are-listener/16526/14).

Replace the discoveryFailuresModalView with a unified connectivityStatusModalView, which is also suitable for displaying
listener failures and status for diagnosis.  Include some short descriptions about what each category means.

Summarize the running listeners in addition to the failed ones in a new array $scope.listenersRunning.

Fixes #7743.

**TODO:**
* [x] Include additional information about running (not failed) discovery mechanisms in the `/rest/system/status` API response.  Currently the discovery status dialog is empty without failures, because the info is just not there.
* [x] Possibly change the label for "Listeners" and "Discovery" as discussed in the forum thread.
* [x] Use different icons for the two dialog variants.

### Testing

* Provoked a discovery failure by enabling local discovery for two instances on the same machine --> shows error.
* Provoked a listener failure by manually setting a port below 1024 for the QUIC listener --> shows error.
* Verified that no errors are displayed when all is good.

![Screenshot_2021-03-30 devtest Syncthing_listenerFailures](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/6996887/113059301-96308a80-91af-11eb-9ed5-a85726551d14.png)

Minor GUI usability change, no changed or removed functionality.

**~~If the labels end up being revised, screenshots and / or docs need to be revisited.~~**

Set the encrypted version counter to the sum of all real counters, instead of using `time.Now()`. Thus all trusted device agree on the version and sending an index for an already existing file-version to an untrusted device doesn't change their version, which did confuse their remote completion.

Remove expired pending folders without relying on timing. Also changed the update function signature to take a `ObservedFolder` instead of `string, string`, such that one can't switch label and id by mistake.

### Purpose

Raises the UDP buffer size limit similar to #7417 for docker deployments if the host network isn't used.

### Testing

I did not test it but it is explicitly stated in the docker documentation:

https://docs.docker.com/engine/reference/commandline/run/#configure-namespaced-kernel-parameters-sysctls-at-runtime
Less bad, because it can only be triggered using `/rest/debug/file` and no-one uses that (except if I tell them to :| ).

Adds default ignores. Those are applied when a folder is auto-accepted. When adding a folder in the web UI, it checks if there is a pre-existing `.stignore` file at the new folder path (through a new `/rest/system/readignores` endpoint), and if not uses the defaults.

The defaults are stored in the config folder in a file named `default-stignore`. The can be modified through the `/rest/db/defaultignores` endpoint. `/rest/db` hardly is the right place for this, but `/rest/db/ignores` already exists. And it's not obvious to me where to put it: Putting it into an own group feels like overkill (`/rest/ignores/folder/folder-id` and `/rest/ignores/default`) and moving to `/rest/system` isn't much better than `/rest/db`. Suggestions for a better endpoint and filename are welcome :) 

Testing: I can change defaults and they appear when adding a new folder.

#7026 is about unspecific `key not found` errors on sentry. The only one that still gets events is https://sentry.syncthing.net/share/issue/270bbc681e3943f7a121268553e6f2e5/, and that's what I am addressing here:

`panic: repairing sequences: filling Blocks: key not found`

When repairing sequences all local files are deserialized, and apparently sometimes the blocks are indirected (or look like it), but theirs no entry for the hash. Instead of failing db repair and thus making the db entirely broken, the defective file info is now removed from the db - to be rescanned later.

Some related changes: I moved checking/repairing globals out of `recalcMeta` into `getMetaAndCheck`. Having that happen as a side effect of recalculating metadata is plain confusing (and I probably wrote that code :) ).  
And the db migration 15 (which uses `recalcMeta`), is redundant with 16 (the meta just gets recalculated twice) - thus removed.
https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fitt's_law
Generalises the confirmation dialog for deleting items added to receive-encrypted folders to also handle reverting/overriding receive/send-only folders (fixes #7520).

When a receive-only folder is added, we don't have the folder token yet. However that is required to ensure a correct (consistent when there's more than 1 device) password. Thus we need to drop and reestablish the connection to ensure the remote sends the cluster-config with the token.

Fixes #7509 by adding a method to the connection to set new folder passwords. This means that any connection may become (partly) encrypted. Thus there's no longer two separate factory methods, but every connection is a `encryptedConnection`.

The passwords on the connection are (re-)set when sending cluster-configs, meaning when a new connection is added, when a new folder is added or when a folder changes.

### Purpose

Docs presented [here](https://docs.syncthing.net/users/autostart.html#linux) states that in order to create systemd service, one should copy proper file from git from `Syncthing/etc/linux-systemd` directory and start it with `systemctl`. However, configuration in this files run `/usr/bin/syncthing serve --no-browser --no-restart --logflags=0` and it seems that `serve` command is no longer accepted. 

### Testing

I have successfully run service without `serve` (the same did creator of #7363).

### Documentation

I guess no docs need to be updated. I can't  `serve` option anywhere in docs.

### Purpose

Scenario (https://github.com/syncthing/syncthing/issues/7474#issuecomment-798881296):

> The reason is that we have an "efficiency" measure: We do not pull items that are not present at all locally and globally invalid or deleted. B sees valid items from A, thus their global is valid. C only sees invalid items from B, thus their global is invalid and they don't pull. B doesn't know about C's global, thus shows C as out of sync. The fix here is to always pull invalid files ("pull" as in create a local invalid entry too).

I adjusted `Need` to consider invalid files needed, and added a shortcut to the puller to send invalid files directly to the db. If at some point we do create a local file, that "trumps" the invalid file as usual (bumps the version of the invalid file, uninvalidates it, ...).

I also added a db migration to trigger a repair, otherwise the changes don't take effect.

### Testing

Unit test checking that we do pull and send back an invalid file info.  
Needed to add some machinery to the fake connection to correctly send invalid files.

And they aren't consistent in whether they include "receiving" and "message". I always added the former (the same method names exist for sending) and removed the latter.

I can't think of any reason why we shouldn't test both the source and target path for case-conflicts, so I assume that was an oversight. It's not problematic in our usage, because in the puller we always check both source and target files against db (i.e. stat them) before renaming, but it still seems like the right/save thing to do.

This truncates times meant for API consumption to second precision,
where fractions won't typically matter or add any value. Exception to
this is timestamps on logs and events, and of course I'm not touching
things like file metadata.

I'm not 100% certain this is an exhaustive change, but it's the things I
found by grepping and following the breadcrumbs from lib/api...

I also considered general-but-ugly solutions, like having the API
serializer itself do reflection magic or even regexp magic on returned
objects, but decided against it because aurgh...

Currently the help is quite broken, as kong handles any occurrence of `-h` or `--help`. E.g.  
```
$ ./bin/syncthing cli --home=./config-testing show -h
Usage: syncthing cli [<args> ...]

Command line interface for Syncthing

Arguments:
  [<args> ...]

Flags:
  -h, --help                  Show context-sensitive help.

      --gui-address=URL       Override GUI address (e.g.
                              "http://192.0.2.42:8443")
      --gui-apikey=API-KEY    Override GUI API key
      --home=PATH             Set configuration and data directory
      --conf=PATH             Set configuration directory (config and keys)
```

To fix that it now detects if the `cli` subcommand is used or not before doing any parsing. Thus the entire parsing happens either through kong or urfave/cli, never a mixture (I asked upstream about a "pass-through" mechanism in kong, which does not exist yet and this workaround has been suggested: https://github.com/alecthomas/kong/issues/151).

I removed the db reset operation: I don't think that should be so easily available. I also added a warning to the override operation. Instead I added an `api` subcommand to directly interact with the api, which can be used if an operation isn't provided directly under `show` or `operations`.

strelaysrv hung on startup because it uses the config wrapper, but the config wrapper needs to be running as a service. The comments on the constructor says this, but the returned type isn't actually a suture.Service so it's cumbersome and non-obvious to use. I fixed that by making it a service as I didn't see any reason for it being otherwise.

Regression introduced in #7384: Previously we always created a new versioning object. That was changed on purpose to not clobber existing values, however the case that there's no existing object wasn't dealt with.
This fixes #7446 by adding the `name:"no-console"` tag. I also moved it into a separate file with build tags, such that it only shows up on windows as before, because why not.

There are timing parameters to catch frequent failure restarts in our monitor, and exit with an error. Systemd units also have such a mechanism by default, but with much less strict parameters that often allow infinite restart loops in case of DB problems. One example is this report, where a single user sent 3.5k events in a few hours: https://sentry.syncthing.net/syncthing/syncthing/issues/8679

Now the same restart parameters are used in the monitor as in the systemd service.

This adds a button in the top right that changes the config back to the default theme. Code wise, it takes the header that was previously a part of the dashboard component and moves it to the app component, and then adds the button there. Possibly the header should be a component of it's own, but that's more of refactor that can happen separately I think. The config change uses the new config API to just patch the relevant setting. I'm not going an automatic reload because 1) I don't want to figure out how to do it correctly and 2) this doesn't work reliably anyway, as for example the current gen GUI does a reload and ends up with connection refused as the API service is still reloading...

Companion to https://github.com/syncthing/syncthing/pull/7417:  
Quic needs the `SetReadBuffer` method available on `net.UdpConn`, that's not part of the `net.PacketConn` and gets "lost" in the stun connection wrapping. I thus add a small wrapper that bundles the stun conn with the original conn to expose `SetReadBuffer` of the original conn.

I noticed there wasn't any time-stamps in logs when running tests. Turns out the defaults set at runtime for command line flags are overriden with null values by kong. I fixed that using kongs "templating".

### Purpose

Another step towards better database error handling (#5907), fixing #7419: Now `db.FileSet.Snapshot` returns an error instead of panicking.  
Most of the diff is boilerplate of adding error returns all over the place. One larger change regards folder error handling: Previously we did not bubble errors consistently (as in already existing errors unrelated to this PR). Now we do need errors in `Serve` to shut the service down in case of fatal errors. I thus opted to bubble "folder-level" errors (as opposed to item level errors, e.g. errors scanning/pulling an item) up to the main loop in the service. That means the folder state is set with any error that reaches that point and isn't fatal. 

### Testing

Existing unit tests pass and the UI still comes up - haven't done any manual testing beyond that.

### Purpose

This PR provides a sysctl configuration to increase the maximum receive socket buffer on Linux as suggest by https://github.com/lucas-clemente/quic-go/wiki/UDP-Receive-Buffer-Size

The configuration gets placed in `/usr/lib/sysctl.d` according to [sysctl.d(5)](https://manpages.ubuntu.com/manpages/focal/en/man5/sysctl.d.5.html). The prefix `30-` causes the file to be applied early as the processing is done in lexicographic order. This should be low enough that configuration files of other packages can still overwrite this value.

I picked the `30-` prefix so that the file can be also used for manual installs in `/etc/sysctl.d` according to the older naming schema in Ubuntu Bionic:

>  Other packages install their files in the 30-*.conf range, to override system defaults.

I also modified the `post-upgrade` script to call `deb-systemd-invoke restart procps.service`

See also #7146
This removes the Badger code that has anyway been disabled for a while now (7892547873c805ef4066f68ea1097d083a759725).

This loosens the ‘is this localhost?’ check to include *.localhost host
names.

This allows for clearer (hence better) names to be used in browsers,
e.g. when accessing a remote syncthing instance ‘foo’ using a ssh port
forward, one can use foo.localhost to remind oneself which one is which.
💡 Without these changes, Syncthing shows a ‘Host check error’ when
pointing a browser at http://foo.localhost/, and with these changes, the
interface loads as usual.

The .localhost top level domain is a reserved top-level domain (RFC 2606):

> The ".localhost" TLD has traditionally been statically defined in
> host DNS implementations as having an A record pointing to the
> loop back IP address and is reserved for such use.  Any other use
> would conflict with widely deployed code which assumes this use.
> – https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc2606

As Wikipedia puts it:

> This allows the use of these names for either documentation purposes
or in local testing scenarios. – https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/.localhost

On Linux systems, systemd-resolved resolves *.localhost, on purpose:
https://www.freedesktop.org/software/systemd/man/systemd-resolved.service.html

See also #4815, #4816.

This sprinkles `BufferPool.Put` in a lot of early returns due to errors. And there's one instance where we used the buffer after putting it back for debug logging.

I look at this because of an unusually large memory usage in the buffer-pool (see https://forum.syncthing.net/t/syncthing-using-all-ram-and-then-locking-up-the-system/16400). I don't expect the fixes in this PR to be the culprit for that usage though, as the errors are unlikely (marshalling, compression, ...).

Here's three minor changes for the encrypted filename handling in lib/protocol:

* The base32.Encoding object that encryptName and decryptName use is allocated once, instead of in every call. This also counts as DRY, since both functions necessarily use the same encoding.
* deslashify now does some light input validation. It used to strip out any occurrences of ".syncthing-enc", without requiring that string to even occur. It now checks for that string in the exact place where it should appear, and removes it only there.
* The tests cover more cases and more extensively check encryptName output.

I don't believe any of these changes address any existing issues; they just protect against potential future mistakes.

The code in GUI uses a wrong key for the versioning path: It should be `fsPath`, but used is `versionsPath`. I changed the fs related options (path and type) to be members of `VersioningConfiguration` directly instead of the "free-form" string map entries. That doesn't prevent any such mixups in JS land, but at least makes it unambiguous in Go (and anything that will be based on the protos :) ).

`insync` isn't a very descriptive name, thus proposing to change it to `restart-required` as brought up in https://github.com/syncthing/docs/pull/616. The currently incorrect docs can then be switched to reference `restart-required`.

Add various tweaks to the Restore Versions modal in order to make it
more usable in general, and also to prevent the content from breaking
when used with long filenames and on small resolutions.

The specific changes are as follows.

1. Contain the file list in a resizable box, which by defaults occupies
   as much space as needed without overflowing the screen vertically.
   This prevents the whole body from being pushed down by the list, and
   also keeps the filter and confirmation buttons visible on the screen.
2. Forcefully break long filenames with no spaces, so that they always
   fit on the screen.
3. Change the position of the restore buttons' menu popup to the left,
   so that it does not go out of the screen on small resolutions.
4. Widen the filter input fields, so that there is more space for the
   text, and especially the data range fits without being cut off.

Signed-off-by: Tomasz Wilczyński <twilczynski@naver.com>

### Testing

Tested in Chromium, Firefox, and IE11*.

\* The browser does not support `resize: both`, so the container is not user-resizable, but it is still usable nevertheless.

Fixes #7385 by only checking for infinite recursion if the junctions-as-dirs option is enabled.

Passing around options like I did in #7381 is tedious/repetitive. I thus changed the way options work from passing function `With...` style arguments to const/bitmask options. This allows knowing what options are active on any given filesystem, thus we don't need to pass options to the case- and walk-fs (and the case-fs can directly use option value for the key instead of constructing some arbitrary string).

One choice I am unsure about: I kept the variable length `opts ...FilesystemOptions` argument, even though multiple options can be passed by bitwise-or-ing options. I left that such that all `NewFilesystem` calls without options don't need to be changed to have an additional `, 0` (or something like `0, fs.OptionNone`) argument.

I was looking for test tooling to time tests (found [gotestsum](https://github.com/gotestyourself/gotestsum)) and in the process stumbled over [counterfeiter](https://github.com/maxbrunsfeld/counterfeiter): It generates functional test classes for any given interface. As I was annoyed by having to change the various `lib/api/mocked_...` types to make tests pass in the past, I very much appreciate the idea of having those generated automatically. There's more boilerplate to get rid of in the fake connection in model testing. And the mocked classes provide lots of functionality (controlling what functions do, providing info on which functions were called including arguments, ...) which we could make use of (I guess a lot of the request_test.go stuff could be simplified.

The mocks are created with go:generate, i.e. there's now more assets to generate. I refactored the lazy asset building to work on a list of assets, and rebuild those which are necessary. An asset specifies a list of source and destination paths, which are all walked to get the newest time (and missing root means rebuild too).

There's one ugly hack: The mocked classes always include a reference to the interface. That can lead to cyclic imports. And it seems unlikely that's going to change given the upstream history: https://github.com/maxbrunsfeld/counterfeiter/issues/121. Thus I added a generation script to remove this reference from the generated code for one protocol interface that we do use in protocol tests.
Adds a new tag to distinguish panics from failures (events) in sentry. There's a lot of noise in sentry (also signal), and I'd like to have a way to see all failure events at a glance.

the time when it was last available. Right now, due to the very long
address field, it is usually necessary to scroll down in order to view
the "Last seen" field.

This change does the following:

- Changes to use the kong command line parser instead of the flag
  package from the standard library. Kong is awesome; I'm deliberately
  using only a fraction of the features here in order to make the change
  smaller to begin with. Feel free to read up on
  https://github.com/alecthomas/kong and then come back here, I'll wait.

- Makes the current mode of operation a subcommand of syncthing,
  `syncthing serve`. The purpose of this is to enable other syncthing
  subcommands in the near future.

- Attempts to clean up and combine environment variables with command
  line flags to a greater extent. This means creating a number of new
  command line flags that were previously environment variables only,
  and passing them explicitly to where they're needed instead of by
  environment magic.  There's probably more that could be done here, but
  I didn't want to go overboard.

This is a backwards compatible change, with a single exception. That is,
any valid command line from before this change should be a valid command
line now as well, and the same environment variables still do the same
things.

The exception is `syncthing --help` which, being a top level help
command, now lists the available subcommands instead of the previous
output. The new way to get the regular help output is `syncthing serve
--help`.

Kong, like most other modern command line parsers, doesn't understand
single-dashed long options (instead it has short options, which we
currently don't have any). To facilitate the transition we handle the
case where no subcommand is given and translate invalid -options to new
style --options. This mean `syncthing -home foo` is accepted and
equivalent to `syncthing serve --home foo`. Note that you *can't* say
`syncthing serve -home foo` -- once you've opted in to saying an
explicit subcommand it's expected that you follow the new syntax and use
proper long options.

For reference, this is the new help output:

```
% syncthing --help
Usage: syncthing <command>

Flags:
  -h, --help    Show context-sensitive help.

Commands:
  serve
    Run Syncthing

Run "syncthing <command> --help" for more information on a command.
```

and then:

```
% syncthing serve --help
Usage: syncthing serve

Run Syncthing

Flags:
  -h, --help                                      Show context-sensitive help.

      --allow-newer-config                        Allow loading newer than current config version
      --audit                                     Write events to audit file
      --auditfile=PATH                            Specify audit file (use "-" for stdout, "--" for stderr)
      --browser-only                              Open GUI in browser
      --conf=PATH                                 Set configuration directory (config and keys)
      --data=PATH                                 Set data directory (database and logs)
      --device-id                                 Show the device ID
      --generate=PATH                             Generate key and config in specified dir, then exit
      --gui-address=URL                           Override GUI address (e.g. "http://192.0.2.42:8443")
      --gui-apikey=API-KEY                        Override GUI API key
      --hide-console                              Hide console window (Windows only)
      --home=PATH                                 Set configuration and data directory
      --log-file=PATH                             Log file name (see below)
      --log-flags=BITS                            Select information in log line prefix (see below)
      --log-max-old-files=N                       Number of old files to keep (zero to keep only current)
      --log-max-size=BYTES                        Maximum size of any file (zero to disable log rotation)
      --no-browser                                Do not start browser
      --no-restart                                Do not restart Syncthing when exiting due to API/GUI command, upgrade, or crash ($STNORESTART)
      --no-default-folder                         Don't create the "default" folder on first startup ($STNODEFAULTFOLDER)
      --no-upgrade                                Disable automatic upgrades ($STNOUPGRADE)
      --paths                                     Show configuration paths
      --paused                                    Start with all devices and folders paused
      --unpaused                                  Start with all devices and folders unpaused
      --upgrade                                   Perform upgrade
      --upgrade-check                             Check for available upgrade
      --upgrade-to=URL                            Force upgrade directly from specified URL
      --verbose                                   Print verbose log output
      --version                                   Show version
      --debug-block-profiler                      Write block profiles to block-$pid-$timestamp.pprof every 20 seconds ($STBLOCKPROFILE)
      --debug-cpu-profile                         Write a CPU profile to cpu-$pid.pprof on exit ($CPUPROFILE)
      --debug-db-indirect-gc-interval=DURATION    Database indirection GC interval ($STGCINDIRECTEVERY)
      --debug-db-recheck-interval=DURATION        Database metadata recalculation interval ($STRECHECKDBEVERY)
      --debug-deadlock-timeout=SECONDS            Used for debugging internal deadlocks ($STDEADLOCKTIMEOUT)
      --debug-gui-assets-dir=PATH                 Directory to load GUI assets from ($STGUIASSETS)
      --debug-heap-profile                        Write heap profiles to heap-$pid-$timestamp.pprof each time heap usage increases ($STHEAPPROFILE)
      --debug-network-profiler-url=URL            Network profiler listen URL ($STPROFILER)
      --debug-perf-stats                          Write running performance statistics to perf-$pid.csv (Unix only) ($STPERFSTATS)
      --reset-database                            Reset the database, forcing a full rescan and resync
      --reset-deltas                              Reset delta index IDs, forcing a full index exchange

The -logflags value is a sum of the following:

(same logflags output)

Development Settings
--------------------

The following environment variables modify Syncthing's behavior in ways that
are mostly useful for developers. Use with care. See also the --debug-* options
above.

 STTRACE           A comma separated string of facilities to trace. The valid
                   facility strings are listed below.

 STDEADLOCKTIMEOUT Used for debugging internal deadlocks; sets debug
                   sensitivity. Use only under direction of a developer.

 STLOCKTHRESHOLD   Used for debugging internal deadlocks; sets debug
                   sensitivity.  Use only under direction of a developer.

 STHASHING         Select the SHA256 hashing package to use. Possible values
                   are "standard" for the Go standard library implementation,
                   "minio" for the github.com/minio/sha256-simd implementation,
                   and blank (the default) for auto detection.

 GOMAXPROCS        Set the maximum number of CPU cores to use. Defaults to all
                   available CPU cores.

 GOGC              Percentage of heap growth at which to trigger GC. Default is
                   100. Lower numbers keep peak memory usage down, at the price
                   of CPU usage (i.e. performance).

Debugging Facilities
--------------------

(same debugging facilities)
```

This halves the size of cache entries on amd64 (32 bytes -> 16 bytes). A quick simulation suggest the total memory footprint should get about a third smaller: I put strconv.Itoa(j) for j = 0 through 10000 in a cache and saw the allocation rate go down from 1.91 to 1.31 MiB.

This removes an unused field and applies a very minor optimization.

`folder.scanSubdirs` is really long and has some ugly variable scopes, mainly regarding db snapshots. Separating the two phases of the scan (walking filesystem to get new/changed files and walking the db to find deleted and ignored files), as well as the folder-type specific shenanigans into separate functions creates nice scopes for db snapshots. And is more readable in my opinion.

There's no behaviour change in this PR at all - only code being moved around.

Adds the block offset as additional data into the AES-SIV encryption of the block hash, thus making it not possible to correlate blocks at different offsets within a file. (These are never decrypted so there is no "other side" to this change.)

Now we return a progress of `blockSize / 2` for files with a single block. That means that the reported progress is potentially larger than the total amount of bytes to sync in total. That leads to the 100% progress reported from the start reported in #7263.

Because I felt like it I adjusted the bytes estimate to be based on the probability that the small block is part of the given number of blocks, based on the total number of blocks in the file. That returns the actual file size for single block files, which fixes the above problem (which could obviously have been achieved in a much simpler way). For larger files the estimate will be a bit "better", probably entirely unnoticeably better.

A user reported very slow scans and looking at a crazy volume of FS debug logs revealed that the rename detection is inefficient if a lot of data is newly scanned that contains a lot of duplicates. Not a very common case, but still something that's simple to improve on by caching not only files that were already detected as deleted/renamed, but also files that were already checked with `IsDeleted` during rename detection.

I also added a check for the filename of the file for which we want to find duplicates and "delete" the cache map afterwards, as it isn't used any more but the function might live on for quite some time.

scanner.Blocks promises, in a comment, to allocate space "once and for all" if it knows the file size. It only did so, however, when the block size divided the file size. The pre-allocation now works as intended for files of all sizes.

Release notes

Sourced from google.golang.org/protobuf's releases.

v1.25.0

  • Overview
  • Notable changes
    • Specialized support for well-known types
  • Upcoming breakage changes

Overview

This release provides specialized support for well-known types.

Notable changes

New features:

  • CL/225298: types/known: implement first-class WKT support
    • Related follow-up changes: CL/237920, CL/237997, CL/238007, CL/238009
  • CL/237219: types/dynamicpb: add NewEnumType

Minor changes:

  • CL/238002: reflect/protoreflect: optimize Name.IsValid and FullName.IsValid
  • CL/239339: cmd/protoc-gen-go: use of --version flag exits with 0

Bug fixes:

  • CL/236998: encoding/protojson: strict validation of FieldMask serialization

Specialized support for well-known types

This release provides specialized support for well-known types by directly generating methods and functions into the generated package for certain well-known types that improve the usability of such types. The additionally generated APIs are listed below.

  • Package anypb: New, MarshalFrom, UnmarshalTo, UnmarshalNew, Any.MessageIs, Any.MessageName, Any.MarshalFrom, Any.UnmarshalTo, Any.UnmarshalNew

  • Package timestamppb: Now, New, Timestamp.AsTime, Timestamp.IsValid, Timestamp.CheckValid

  • Package durationpb: New, Duration.AsDuration, Duration.IsValid, Duration.CheckValid

  • Package structpb: NewStruct, Struct.AsMap, Struct.MarshalJSON, Struct.UnmarshalJSON, NewList, ListValue.AsSlice, ListValue.MarshalJSON, ListValue.UnmarshalJSON, NewValue, NewNullValue, NewBoolValue, NewNumberValue, NewStringValue, NewStructValue, NewListValue, Value.AsInterface, Value.MarshalJSON, Value.UnmarshalJSON

  • Package fieldmaskpb New,, Union,, Intersect,, FieldMask.IsValid,, FieldMask.Append,, FieldMask.Normalize,

  • Package wrapperspb Bool, Int32, Int64, UInt32, UInt64, Float, Double, String, Bytes

Upcoming breakage changes

There are no new upcoming breaking changes to announce in this release.

As a reminder, the following have already been announced and may take effect in the near future:

  • Deprecations announced on 2020-03-02 with the v1.20.0 release

As discussed in https://github.com/syncthing/syncthing/pull/7276 I implemented storing the case-resolver results in an lru&lfu cache (github.com/hashicorp/golang-lru).

A solution without golang-lru, i.e. doing locking and counting ourselves, is not much more complex. That solution is in the intermediary commit: aee7ea1717ad3e93c4e81414783ed0ec2febb741 / diff: https://github.com/syncthing/syncthing/pull/7286/files/aa1ffcaebfa12b4b6b5e6df53a3a7f7621674845

I extended the existing case-fs benchmark (on second walk we stat every path component, not just full path) and I added a new benchmark that does an unrelated lstat every 1000. item in the regular walk. To simulate stuff like api/incoming requests. To make benchmarking more relevant, I added read-locking without changing caching in a first commit, and compare against that.

The results are pretty clear for number of `DirNames` calls: Small, but significant reduction with random other calls, and no difference with or without golang-lru (and no changes for "just" walking):

lock vs with:

```
name                                          old DirNames/op     new DirNames/op     delta
WalkCaseFakeFS100k/casefs-otherOpEvery1000-8           104k ± 0%           102k ± 0%   -1.32%  (p=0.000 n=10+18)
```

lock vs without:

```
name                                          old DirNames/op     new DirNames/op     delta
WalkCaseFakeFS100k/casefs-otherOpEvery1000-8           104k ± 0%           102k ± 0%   -1.32%  (p=0.000 n=10+18)
```

With a cache is a bit slower:

without vs with

```
name                                          old ns/entry        new ns/entry        delta
WalkCaseFakeFS100k/casefs-8                           5.36k ±15%          6.82k ± 5%  +27.19%  (p=0.000 n=19+10)

Two-phase locking alone is pretty straight forward to add, but isn't helpful on its own:

Currently we have the directory contents as an array for every path component of the cached entry. So if we look up `/foo/bar/baz/quux` and then afterwards `/foo/bar/baz/asdf` we don't need to make an fs call, but we do need to loop through the cached childs of `/foo/bar/baz/` and then we update the cache to have `asdf` as leaf instead of `quux`.

In this PR the result of the last component are not stored, i.e. `asdf` and `quux` in the example above. That would remove the need for modification/write locks when stating lots of files in the same directory. However if another call on an unrelated path comes in between, that will change the cache and thus require acquiring write-locks. Where this does help is for fs operations in the folder root, e.g. stating `.stfolder`, which will now no longer cause any modification/lock and also will not drop the cache anymore. In the wast majority of cases where the operations are on unrelated paths (e.g. requests), we'll still modify/lock/drop cache. To fix that, some tree-ish option would help, where cache can be kept in more than a single branch. Problem there is that the size of that cache can grow fast.

### Purpose

Fixes reported issue #7267

### Testing

1) Open logging modal
2) Scroll to top to stop log-tailing
3) Close modal
4) Reopen modal and see log-tailing resumes and displays log instead of blank textarea as shown in issue repoort

This splits the ignore getting to two methods, one that loads from disk
(the old one) and one that just returns whatever is already loaded (the
new one). The folder summary service which is just interested in stats
now uses the latter method. This means that it, and API calls that call
it, does not get blocked by folder I/O.

This makes it faster to get a caseFs when it's already cached, which it almost always is. It also moves the filesystem touching things in the request path to until after we've passed the limiter, so that we block there instead on the casefs lock.
On Linux, memorySize in lib/ur would open /proc/meminfo but never close it.

The test would fail if the umask on UNIX is greater than 0022, because
the OS transparently subtracts it from the mode passed to Mkdir(), as
the Go documentation confirms.

Our goal here is not to test os.Mkdir(), so just make sure the desired
mode is actually set by forcing it afterwards.

Filesystems are created/stored redundantly in folders: The basic filesystem lives in the folder config, the mtime-fs is created in the model and passed to folder factories, where it is stored in `sendReceiveFolder` only, but created again on every scan in `folder`. Now it isn't passed in the factory anymore and lives as `folder.mtimefs`, thus being available in all folders.

This saves us the massive amount of 4 lines of code (and shortens some lines) :)

When deleting a directory we check it's contents. However we do so only superficially, i.e. do not recursive into child directories. And items that match a `(?d)` ignore pattern are removed with `RemoveAll` (and errors are swallowed). This means that if an item within such `(?d)`-dirs is un-ignored (`!`), it gets removed too (unit test exercises this scenario). I don't think this is a big issue - I wouldn't expect anyone to mark something for deletion that may contain valuable files. Nevertheless it's wrong.  
Now we walk the directory to be removed, thus find any non-ignored children of children, and use `Remove`, not `RemoveAll`.

Index-senders are unblocked/cleaned up when the underlying connection closes, however not when they fail on their own due to a db error. Now there's an additional channel that gets closed when the index-sender stops, and that's used instead of the connection to unblock method calls.

And there was a copy&paste error when cleaning up index-senders of folders no longer mentioned in a cluster-config.

When adding a folder from the pending folder from another device
through the Add button on the "New Folder" notification panel, the
offering device should be preselected for sharing with.  The selection
works, but the checkmark for that device is not shown at all.

Do not filter out the preselected device ID when building the
currentSharing.unrelated member in addFolderAndShare() to actually
show all devices under the "Unshared Devices" heading.

### Testing

Tested with local development instance where several folders are pending from other devices.  Offering device appears again, with the checkmark pre-selected.  Also verified on the "untrusted" GUI variant.

Add a `-types` flag which can be set to a comma-separated list of event
types.  The contents will be included verbatim in the URL parameter
`events`.

### Testing

Tested against a devopment instance of Syncthing running locally, with two event types specified.

The merge of #6443 apparently introduced a wrong argument name in
$scope.ignoreFolder().  This fixes the regression.

### Purpose

As discussed in #7196, there might be some scenarios where a relay server might want to advertise itself from a different IP address from which it is actually listening on. This is currently not possible, as the relay pool server rejects join requests whose advertised remote address does not match the address used to make the join request.

This PR enables relay servers to send their TLS certificate in the join requests, provided the pool is contacted via https. The relay pool server will capture this certificate, generate the Device ID from it, and compare it to the advertised device ID. If they do not match, the request is rejected straight away.

This ensures that the agent sending the join request is indeed in possession of the key corresponding to the advertised device ID. This advertised device ID is later checked to be the same as the one behind the advertised IP address as a part of the original connection test by `performHandshakeAndValidation` on: https://github.com/syncthing/syncthing/blob/d904dfa1918ae09a7af38c75945903ba494fd21f/lib/relay/client/static.go#L240-L242

While this check is only triggered if `uri.Query().Get("id") != ""`, this is ensured by the mismatch check mentioned earlier.

### Testing

Very basic tested was performed locally by building a relay server and a pool server with the changes, and checking that they were able to exchange and validate the certificates. Please comment if you think more testing (automated or not) is desired for this.

### Purpose

From https://github.com/syncthing/syncthing/issues/7165:
> Came up starting in #7141 (comment), short summary: A protocol connection doesn't control the underlying tls connection, thus it cannot close it. All the methods that supposedly close it, just tell the model that it's closed and potentielly send a Closed BEP msg, but don't actually close the connection.

What I did is to move the entire connection interface to lib/protocol, and pass the necessary pieces (closer and connection info) to from lib/connections to lib/protocol. The main advantage is that the protocol can now close the underlying connection on any error. Additional it's also a bit cleaner, removing some type aggregation and an interface in lib/connections.

### Testing

No new tests. The changes are just adjustments to the new API.  
My testing is nothing more than: Connections still do drop and reconnect on pause/unpause.

### Purpose

When anyone calls `FileSet.IndexID` and the local one is zero, we create a new one. Thus two goroutines calling it concurrently may return two different IDs, and the later one will be persisted. I realised this because of logs connected to https://forum.syncthing.net/t/mismatching-index-id-for-us-on-almost-every-restart-again/16036/8:
```
129:[RTF25] 14:24:38 INFO: Device DWJVRMJ-... folder "A" (a) has mismatching index ID for us (0xA0175C8807ED7CBB != 0x42C01C3C03087F58)
[...]
566:[RTF25] 15:10:32 INFO: Device DWJVRMJ-... folder "A" (a) has mismatching index ID for us (0x42C01C3C03087F58 != 0x6F4E1206A392035F)
```

However it still seems quite improbable: The race would be between any incoming and any outgoing CC (both call `IndexID`). Then again, there's quite a few devices and folders in that log, so why not.

This is a proposal to make config changes in the current system less prone to races. It is thus related to #5298, however clearly does not address all the issues brought up there nor is it intending to.

It was prompted by the review comment about the order of initialising folders in the model and subscribing to config changes here: https://github.com/syncthing/syncthing/pull/7150#discussion_r537010460  
That's inherently racy as it is, regardless of the order in which order it's done.

The proposed change here is that changes to the config only go ahead once all calls to `.CommitConfiguration` due to the previous change returned. If multiple config changes are outstanding, they will applied in the same order as the config change method (e.g. `SetFolder`) was called.  
In addition with `.Subscribe` returning the currently active config, this allows a subscriber to subscribe to config changes, use the returned config for initialisation, and then start processing config changes. Thus starting with subscribing, they get all config changes sequentially in the correct order. Which I have done for `model`.

The obvious potential for problems here is locking. Previously anyone changing the config was only blocked until all previous config changes were dispatched asynchronously. Now blocking happens until all previous config changes took effect. If a subscriber is changing the config while holding a lock, that the subscriber also acquires on `CommitConfiguration`, that can deadlock. However doing that is also problematic today (can cause concurrent `CommitConfiguration` calls, which is also very bad) and we are aware of it, as e.g. evident in this comment:

```golang
	// Needs to happen outside of the fmut, as can cause CommitConfiguration
```

I added an explicit clause to the comment on the `Committer` interface, which obviously doesn't guarantee anything, but might increase awareness.

This PR just adds awareness of slashified paths to existing methods that check if a given path could have been auto-generated by our encryption code (of course it's still possible to create an extraneous dir that looks like an encrypted one to sneak past this detection, that's not an issue though, we'll just ignore it (or delete if empty)). This does not address the point brought up in #7184 that it might be better to just not care about extraneous stuff in encrypted folders at all, it just fixes the behaviour as it is.

The logs on my nightly devices get filled with this quic stuff that they write directly to the default logger of the `log` package (#7146). I hope they will reconsider that practice, but until then lets discard it to not drown relevant logging. Alternatively we could redirect it to a new debug logging facility (e.g. `logger` or `external`) but that seems pointless as noone will ever remember it exists or notice when debugging, given how generic it would be.

If a fatal error should be reported, chances are good we are getting shut down before they can be reported. To mitigate that unsent reports are written to disk when the service stops and these failures are then reported on next startup.

Moves `sanitizePath` from model to `fs.SanitizePath` and in addition to what it already sanitizes, it now also adds an underscore to windows reserved names, fixing #7075.

#7138 actually has a proper bug as a cause :) 

We do reload the UI when the theme was changed by the user, in the success callback of the api call changing the config. However that call errors out, as it waits for the config change to take place, and while doing so the config change restarts the api server, terminating all outstanding api calls. Now we are giving the API a chance to shut down gracefully, and thus the config change succeeds.

The problem in #7152 is the trailer we add to the file containing the encrypted file info and the connected file size change: We adjust that when actually pulling the file. On index retransfer, we get a new global file, as the version always changes when encrypting a file info. That triggers a pull, but as the contents didn't change, that can be shortcutted. In the shortcut we do not adjust the filesize. So on next scan, the scanner notices the changed file size and thus the file gets marked as locally changed.

Now the file size adjustment happens in the db updater routine of the puller, not in the shared puller state.

Deleted items in a receive-encrypted folder must be tagged as a local change, as we mustn't send them to remotes. However those are not a problem, they are meant to be deleted, and thus shouldn't show up as locally changed. To filter those files out, we need to know the folder type. That information is not available in the db package. Thus in the api, instead of getting a db-snapshot from the model and getting locally changed items from that snapshot, this information is now directly obtained from the model (thus having all of these file list methods (need, remote-need, locally-changed) in the model. instead of spread between model and db).

This is a first step towards graceful error handling in the db layer. It introduces error return values to `NewLowlevel` and `NewFileSet`. That requires a mechanism in the model to handle fatal errors when starting folders, which is just a one-buffered channel for fatal errors that the model service receives from to initiate shutdown.

This means that errors which were previously panics and thus reported now result in a graceful shutdown, i.e. no panic reporting. Thus I introduced failure reporting in the db. The principle is that every package is responsible for reporting it's own failures, even if that failure results in a returned error. The reasoning is, that only at the error source you can know if the error needs reporting and whether it's actually safe to report (e.g. doesn't contain paths or ids).

Previously such fatal failures would hardly ever get reported, as the reporting service gets torn down due to the fatal failure before it sends them. Now unreported failures are written to disk when the service stops and these failures are then reported on next startup.

Added a unit test ensuring that we don't send indexes for locally changed items on receive-encrypted folders.

### Purpose

This change adds a browser for the global state of a folder and reflects which files and directories are ignored. I aim to close #4729, not to build next gen ignores.

It does:
present a browser of files and directories
show each file's status as unaffected, ignored, or included (by a !negated pattern)
match files to simple patterns (anchored at folder root, identifying a specific file)
use client-side parsing and matching for patterns
make use of /rest/db/browse in its current form
have some tests
It will soon:
edit ignore patterns with a checkbox or toggle button
detect advanced patterns, and decline to show the browser view when present
be better integrated with the ignores UI - I don't intend to keep it in its own tab
It does not:
handle "advanced" patterns - wildcards, case insensitivity, etc
prepare for larger scale - large number of files or ignore patterns, pagination
use fancytree for the browser view

### Testing

This change includes Javascript tests! I am happy to split their addition out into a separate issue. I am not familiar with the project's build practices and would need some direction to get them running in CI.

Tests should help build confidence in a complex client side pattern-matching change. See the 'matchingPatterns' block of browseController.test.js for the examples demonstrating which patterns match which files. The controller is tested thoroughly but template is not - I think that's acceptable, it's relatively thin.

To test this change manually, open the folder edit modal and go to the "browse" tab.

### Screenshots

![1](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/2000583/100047889-c8307b00-2dd0-11eb-87e5-3653880aa6fa.png)

### Documentation

I have a change prepared to add a Testing section to syncthing/docs dev/web.rst. Just a couple sentences and a code block describing how to run the karma tests.

It doesn't look like there's a home for any documentation on using the browser. Maybe the Ignoring Files page?

Doing some testing for untrusted feature I noticed that errors processing cluster-config didn't result in the connection being dropped on the remote device. We are currently just closing the underlying connection in that case, not sending a BEP close-message, thus the connection first needs to time out on the remote to be noticed as closed.

Problem:  
If an error occurs while migration the db, we do not update the schema/migration versions in the db. That means if multiple migrations need to take place, and some of them pass successfully but a later one fails, Syncthing stops, restarts and tries to redo the already successful migrations. Which will fail for some, e.g. when trying to read legacy types to convert them.

Fix;  
Now we are writing versions after every successful migration.

This removes the probing for the remote side, instead making it so we
simply construct the address based on the currently connected address,
if any, and let the user sort out whether it works or not.

More fixes regarding races between folders being started and cluster configs being processed based on the logs provided in https://forum.syncthing.net/t/device-stays-out-of-sync-until-restart/15891

The fix for race on incoming cluster-configs in #7100 works, but it's an unclean and partial fix:  
Index senders are started without index info, as the folder/device is new. That's correct for the starting sequence, but it's still bad because we don't store the index id. Meaning on a successive connect, we will re-exchange all index data. That is fixed by always storing the index data received in cluster-configs, even if we don't share the folder so far.  
And we should also resend cluster-configs when adding folders on starting the model - connections may happen before that.

### Testing

Extended the unit test introduced in #7100 to cover this scenario too.

More fixes regarding races between folders being started and cluster configs being processed based on the logs provided in https://forum.syncthing.net/t/device-stays-out-of-sync-until-restart/15891

So far I have looked at incoming cluster-configs only: #7100. That fix works, but it's not an unclean fix: Index senders are started without index info based, as the folder/device is new. That's correct for the starting sequence, but it's still bad because we don't store the index id. Meaning on a successive connect, we will re-exchange all index data. That is fixed by always storing the index data, even if we don't share the folder so far.

There's also an issue with sending cluster configs: When a folder is not paused, but hasn't been started yet, we send an info that says that the folder is running, but there's no index id/sequence. The remote then drops all info on us, while we happily start sending from a non-zero starting sequence once the folder is started. Thus the remote will be missing index info from us. For as long as we don't reset deltas. This problem likely existed for a long time, not just since sending multiple CCs like the problem above that are related to receiving CCs.  
The fix for this is to pretend the folder is paused if it isn't running, even if it isn't paused in config. Then when it is actually started we'll resend the cluster-config including the proper index info.

### Testing

"Alex from the forum" (aka the bug-reproducing log-delivering hero) will see if this prevents them from making remote devices out-of-sync.

The PR is still WIP because of the to-dos below, but it is usable as it is right now.

The branch lives on top of https://github.com/syncthing/syncthing/pull/7127 (first three commits at the time of writing) - I would suggest looking at that first, however if you'd rather have one huge diff, it's available here :) 

The defaults in proto are represented as normal `FolderConfiguration`/`DeviceConfiguration` messages. I added a new `ext.nodefault` proto extension/tag to mark fields which are not configurable (like the id). Those are used to ensure that they are at their zero value when committing a config change. Using the same type allows using it directly as a template for new folders/devices and means there's no duplication.

The defaults can be obtained and set through the rest api on `rest/config/defaults/folder` resp. `.../device` and that endpoint is used instead of the hardcoded values in the GUI (fixes #6068).

### Changed defaults

If the defaults in the GUI did not match those in the config, I chose the GUI ones as those are the ones that were really in effect:

Folder:
 - max conflicts: -1 -> 10
 - min disk free: nothing/unlimited -> 1%

### To-do

 - [x] GUI to modify defaults. Plan is to reuse existing folder and device modals. (Required to really fix #4224).

 - [x] Port gui to untrusted.

optional:

  - [ ] Somehow handle versioning defaults. Currently you can set default versioning for new folders including parameters, but not default parameters for the different versioning types. Not sure whether that's really necessary and the GUI versioning code is a bit messy/verbose, so haven't looked into that yet.

### Testing

I extended the test checking defaults and did some manual fiddling around with config and UI, which looked good (but was likely far from comprehensive).

Working on configurable folder/device defaults, I noticed we do not ensure that the local device is always added to folders. We only check that when creating a new config, which is kind of useless. Adding that check requires the wrapper to know about it's own - which is why all the files not in lib/config changed. And working on `Configuration.prepare` made my head spin, so I decided to split that up into smaller functions and methods on the sub-types. And while at it, I changed `util.SetDefaults` to recurse into structs, such that we only need to call it once at the top-level (the current way is repetitive and prone to error by forgetting a member).

When using a Web browser with JavaScript either disabled or unavailable,
show a warning to let the user know that the Web GUI requires JS in
order to operate.

To achieve this, add a `div` that wraps both the navbar and the main
content, and then move the CSS class `ng-cloak` from the `html` element to
that `div`. This way, only the JavaScript-dependent part is hidden when
JS is unavailable, and not the whole website, as it is the case right
now. Then, add a `<noscript>` element right at the start of the `body`
element, so that the warning is also shown right away in text-based Web
browsers. The `noscript` element includes a stripped down version of the
navbar showing only the Syncthing logo, and then a container with the
warning itself. Lastly, leave the footer untouched and always visible,
because it does not rely on JavaScript at all.

Signed-off-by: Tomasz Wilczyński <twilczynski@naver.com>

Folders which are newly added/shared fell through the cracks regarding sending indexes, as we reject them in cluster config and that's where we initialise index sending. Now in `newFolder` and in `restartFolder` when a folder is shared to a new device, we call a new method `indexSenderRegistry.addNew`. This starts the index sender with no index info (the folder/device is new, we need to transfer everything).

The `/rest/db/file` endpoint already has a good amount of helpful info when debugging weird out-of-sync issues, but it doesn't give the full picture. I added a `/rest/debug/file` endpoint which in addition to the info already contained in `/rest/db/file` also prints the global versions. Thus one can see at a glance all involved devices and at which versions they are (plus if ignored and/or deleted). I named all the involved method with `Debug` and the api data is a string, as it is an internal implementation detail and should not be used for anything but debugging.
We can't use the context in exported functions, as we get it as an argument to `serve` and those functions may be called before/after serve is started/returned.

There's a shortcut that prevents acquiring an IO token for pulling if there's nothing to pull. However that shortcut did not take care of pull errors. Thus if pulling failed, then a remote index comes in such that we don't need the file anymore (e.g. deletion), the earlier failure is never cleared.

As the IO limiting happens in `folder`, and pull errors are managed in `sendReceiveFolder`, I refactored error management: Now all errors are stored in `folder` under a single lock (we never scan and pull at the same time, so having two locks is pointless).

I missed adjusting the debug endpoint in #7001 to the new httprouter library: It doesn't match subpaths automatically, one needs to specify desired matching behaviour. Thus it returned 404s for the debug endpoints.

This removes the switch for using a Badger database, because it has bugs
that it seems there is no interest in fixing, and no actual bug tracker
to track them in.

It retains the actual implementation for the sole purpose of being able
to do the conversion back to LevelDB if anyone is actually running with
USE_BADGER. At some point in a couple of versions we can remove the
implementation as well.

inb4 one hundred dependabot PRs. I did the following:

```
go get -u all  # upgrade everything
grep -v '// indirect' go.mod  # ... except indirect dependencies
go mod tidy  # ... but put back those that are required, and clean checksums
# fix the build for badger
# then revert the badger update because badger is broken anyway
```

Just noticed through #7079 that there's a method whitelist and thus added the new methods used in the `/rest/config` endpoints. And this also fixes an issue with `/rest/config` the only endpoint added in #7001 that I didn't add a test for. Weirdly enough adding the test wouldn't have helped: It doesn't fail (neither does the UI, which uses it too), while it does fail using curl. Anyway, works with curl too now.

### Purpose

Extracted from #7017, I think this change is of general utility.  It reports the HTTP OPTIONS method as part of the allowed methods for the API.  That is normally used as part of the CORS preflight check when doing a GET or POST request.  When just trying to check API availability, a deliberate OPTIONS request is enough, but currently it fails because of the returned `Access-Control-Allow-Methods` header.

I don't see any security risks here and was hoping to get this small change into a release before #7017 is finalized, so that the probing done there actually works with as many instances as possible.

### Testing

Verified that the header is set: `curl -X OPTIONS http://localhost:8384/ -v`.  Tested with Firefox (as part of #7017) that it no longer fails with a [CORS error](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTTP/CORS/Errors/CORSMethodNotFound?utm_source=devtools&utm_medium=firefox-cors-errors&utm_campaign=default) when doing an OPTIONS request from within the JS code.

This is a proposal for adding untrusted folders (encryption) support behind a feature flag, as discussed in https://forum.syncthing.net/t/encryption-merging-scary-changes-feature-flags/15703

The PR branch is an extension of https://github.com/syncthing/syncthing/pull/6727, with the feature flag added and the stdecryptfolder tool removed. That still had outstanding PR reviews and isn't necessary to have in a first iteration for testing this. Other than that I believe I addressed all the PR reviews from there and this should be ready to merge. Of course except for the feature flag code, which no one has reviewed yet.

The feature flag determines which web UI is served: The "traditional" one or the new one with controls for untrusted folders. A missing feature flag does not prevent "manual" config changes that introduce untrusted folders. My reasoning being is that it not being available by default in UI is enough of a barrier to prevent wide adoption. I can add a mechanism in the config layer to prevent untrusted folders without the flag if deemed necessary.

The feature flag itself is just a string, such that it can be reused if we ever want to use a feature flag again, instead of creating ad deprecating a bool every time.

The statics server is adjusted, such that if the feature flag is set, it looks for files in a "untrusted" subdir and serves those instead of the "normal" files if present. Those files are adjusted full copies of the originals, i.e. if other UI changes happen, those need to be kept in sync by hand. That's ugly, but I consider it manageable (thus volunteering xD ).

A large part of the gui diff in https://github.com/syncthing/syncthing/pull/6727 are refactors to make my live easier or prevent duplication. To implement the feature flag and keep the diff minimal, I factored out all those changes that do not change behaviour and that I consider useful even if encryption wouldn't be there:

 - Devices are now tracked as a map internally.

 - Use `$scope.currentSharing` to track sharing changes instead of having "virtual attributes" on the device-/folderconfigs.

Testing: Un-/Sharing folders/devices still works.

This adds a similar db transition mechanism to the one already existing for schema changes. Schema transitions have in the past been "abused" for operations that did not actually change the db. This puts unnecessary limitations on downgrading. The added mechanism is meant to be used in these cases.

I also added the first such repair transition for #7044, which fixes a bug that could lead to corrupt metadata, and thus requires a metadata recalculation.
A clear oversight. Verified manually by checking the logs.

Huge thanks to @tomasz1986 for not letting loose on this issue until discovering a reproducer so... lacking a better word lets say intricate, and also providing all the logs and screenshots I could wish for. Really, this fix is your achievement!

Not much to say about the fix: Stupid little slip. The code in question was even test covered before, but apparently not checked.

There's one question: There's a good chance this affects a few users. Recalculating metadata when releasing the fix seems in order - how should we trigger that? A db transition would work, but is a bit ingenious as there isn't any actual transition. We could also add an "upgrade hook" to syncthing.go that can do arbitrary stuff when updating to specific version, and export the db repair function again to call it there. Better ideas?

The added context on the error/panic message shows the `key not found` error still happens during metadata recalculation:

https://sentry.syncthing.net/syncthing/syncthing/issues/4397/?query=is%3Aunresolved%20version%3Av1.11.0-rc.1

Again it makes no sense at all that we get a `key not found` when deleting a key which just got from an db iterator, but nevertheless ignoring it feels more appropriate than panicking.

Removes context including user info like device IDs from panic message.

Was introduced in #7029, i.e. is RC material.

Manages life-time of index senders. Previously they were only tied to the connection staying alive and new cluster configs, in which case index senders are terminated. Now index senders are also un-/paused together with folders and stopped when removing a folder. When unpausing the newly generated fileset is passed, thus they stay up-to-date with changes in the newly created folder service - which fixes #7034.

This PR does a few related things regarding panics:

 - We have plenty of IO errors from leveldb including the db path, which become panics. Yes they should be errors, yes the goal is still to do that. In the meantime lets remove the paths from the panic message. And anyway, even with errors those would be fatal so the path will have to be filtered eventually.

- Added the panic message to the fingerprint. That's absolutely necessary for https://github.com/syncthing/syncthing/pull/6925, otherwise all events from it will be merged together (as they don't have traces). I also did it for panics to prevent merging different errors with the same trace. There's some pattern matching to prevent stuff like indexes or db paths (old clients without the change above will keep sending them) prevent matching events together.

 - Do not use the fingerprint for pattern matching for db corruption or fatal db io errors. It doesn't matter where those occur. This should reduce the noise in the sentry issue list. This could be extended to other kinds of errors that may occur regardless of time/place. 

No need to tell me the regexyness is terrible (and possibly terrifying), I know it is. I think the benefits are worth the ugliness though, but that's obviously open to discussion.

We use https://github.com/shirou/gopsutil to get disk stats and they expose the values as uint64 (https://github.com/shirou/gopsutil/blob/master/disk/disk.go#L11), which we then convert to int64 for the filesystem interface. It's a minor change on our side and filesystems pretending to be just as large as an int64 are apparently a thing (see https://github.com/syncthing/syncthing/issues/3930#issuecomment-701983666 and issue linked just above that comment). For anything larger https://github.com/shirou/gopsutil would have to use floats or different units in their API (we are already using floats for any further calculations).

### Purpose

Instead of dropping a connection when the config changes, a new cluster config is generated and sent.

On the receiving end this means we need to track index senders to reset them when a new cluster config comes in. There was a commit on the progress emitter that it breaks on multiple CCs. I couldn't figure out though what is supposed to break, the operation has the exact same effect if called on a newly established connection or a super old one.

On the sending side sending of cluster configs happens in the toplevel function now. Otherwise we might send multiple CCs to the same device, which is wasteful. We did wait on the connection being closed previously, which we obviously don't anymore. This was done to prevent incoming indexes to happen after folder objects are removed from the model - I think we previously panicked then. Now if that happens we just drop the connection with an error, which is fine.

### Testing

Adjusted a few tests either to check that a CC is sent instead of connection dropped or to drop a device instead of changing a folder to actually prompt the connection to be closed.  
Also did non-intensive testing on the test setup, i.e. pause and unpause folders verifying that the connection doesn't drop.

### Documentation

Needs a change to the BEP to remove the "must not" on sending multiple cluster configs.

This does what was proposed in #6989: When at the end of syncing a file there's a case-conflict, and the conflicting files have the same content, just keep one of the two names instead of throwing an error. This only handles files and case conflicts in the last path component, as directories are a can of worms: We'd have to check the equality of an entire filesystem sub-tree.

Extended a unit test to cover both the scenario with differing and equal contents on case-conflict.
